2DA53BA4825544F192B6600F4ED7C4DF.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

C35687B6A0C94A38B4BC553187392109.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

F81B03AB6BD148F4AC0C07C541997878.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

F344FB6BE9E24C949072C79A1060FB4C.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

4A113E7D2DC749339C57FC2F06CF86D2.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

44364D99D1EC4FBB8B70EEF1EB1C0F73.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

B7BFAC56C76546DDA98507514BA6E6DC.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

A8904A238FF3470E94E35264E14B38D2.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

6C29F402FB8F4627B2AB61CEEE4DFC71.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

ACADACAAF9404EDFB489F654F8F72731.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

C9F13CDC716341DFBF8B7C77A8499D55.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

7BB77EA902B14259A316C56488DAFE53.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

2D4B1EE4C6114132BE36EFBD24EEA4B4.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

BA063FA5C6444F739B748598BED84378.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training? What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement? Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance? What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided? What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

E5226CF51C7042298E49DD6EAB822AC2.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

88C03A06BE9D42C9B0A1408705B8F7E1.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

EFAF82FEB7E54DA18C47DF47677CAED0.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

746F38C021FF4916B2C5AE7B1BC2A5C9.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

4BFC82A4B15C454C8ED2AFD5987BA32D.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

2BFD9757F6D04EC8AD0E3E938321A4D0.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: • the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and,  the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

09157A5E368A407CAE17C9FF97A2D059.description: Adjust the plan based on feedback received.

6914119DECF1467E905E6B2B97111689.description: Reflect on feedback received from trusted supporters.

77A87C3B6DF64D62832856AF65914F13.description: Pitch the agribusiness idea or concept to trusted supporters.

06A2FAC647874FA3B5FC50C98487C8C9.description: Propose, and develop answers for, questions that may be asked by investors or potential supporters during a business pitch, such as: How big is the market for your idea?,  Who are your competitors and what are their market shares?, What is your competitive advantage?, What is unique about your idea?, How much money are you prepared to invest yourself? and What other sources of finance do you have access to?.

67D08F7CA0404FE4A0BD9105AE3080CA.description: Examine characteristics (e.g., short and concise, tells a story and pays attention to details) of an effective and compelling business pitch.

DCFDDA67E6864BC288AE11ED572F6E1C.description: Outline an agribusiness idea or concept using the business model canvas.

43C32228139A4322B862004F29066B45.description: Examine the components of the business model canvas, including: Value proposition – what the unique business idea is and what it promises to deliver; Customer segments – groups of people or companies to whom the business will target its product or service; Key activities – processes and tasks that need to be completed in order to serve customers; Key resources – resources (e.g., human, tools and financial) required and the source of those resources; Channels – how the business will be marketed to gain and serve customers; Customer relationships – a description of the type of relationship the business will have with customers and how the business will interact with them; Key partners – the external companies or suppliers that will help the business carry out its activities; Cost structure – all anticipated costs for establishing and operating the business; and, Revenue streams – how the business will make money.

80465593E1724ADF92142F3C5068791B.description: Research the business model canvas and how it can be used to visualize and outline a business idea or concept.

FC4808CD3E9347908E83B468EB06CAD8.description: Develop questions that should be answered when planning a start-up, such as: What is the business idea?, What need or want does it fill, or what problem does it solve?, Who are the targeted customers?, How much money and other resources will be required for start-up?, How will money and other resources be obtained? and What other resources are needed?

A354B0F47A1945FC8BE78331F83F62BA.description: Discuss the importance of planning before launching a start-up.

FD1FCF0F5BF2443BB6594CA94FE90393.description: Prepare for and present a business pitch for an agribusiness idea or concept.

D3B6DB4A37174513B2F75EF90C3BB74F.description: Assess various methods (e.g., consumer polls, online surveys and focus groups) for conducting market research.

ACE87791AB1A4251B30F71C5C4DA82D0.description: Examine the role of market research in developing an agribusiness enterprise.

2518DC5A793843929D795914440668D1.description: Differentiate among resources (e.g., technical, human and financial) required by a variety of agribusiness opportunities such as a tire shop, food processor, greenhouse, berry farm or trucking firm.

5E649DF03A764B27BB3AF62726A04D43.description: Identify factors (e.g., public trust, environment and economic) that affect agriculture and agribusiness in the local or regional area.

C82E6FDAB8144637B5F5EB682AD36648.description: Describe the concept of economic viability

7D60D5C0EC014AEEB5A1923FA297CFD8.description: Examine factors that should be considered when exploring an agribusiness enterprise for potential development which may include: availability of inputs; size of the market – current and potential; competitors in the marketplace; access to, and location of, markets; fixed and variable costs; land and building requirements; human resource requirements; packaging, storage and distribution; climate, soil and water conditions; environmental policies; and, zoning regulations.

DC876AF4823D41C58325C2BD569A9AD7.description: Discuss the importance of accessing these resources for informed decision making.

4A545B859CAB42309210D0BCA477A94F.description: Research local, provincial and national resources (e.g., industry organizations, government agencies, websites and financial institutions) that can assist with identifying and developing an agribusiness enterprise.

AB0D65E2909C4E93A0805560D356F4C4.description: Analyze processes for selecting and developing an agribusiness enterprise.

28C7723C2ED34921AE7DEBF7E7D6E1C1.description: Reflect on personal and collective responsibility for, and commitment to, promoting and supporting workplace safety.

5B4819C5AB9749DEAC535E2A6CCC7F52.description: Develop a list of tips for workplace safety that could apply to any agribusiness workplace.

B2FB4E4874FC40ACB893BD5B89486DFA.description: Recommend strategies for preventing workplace injuries associated with the potential hazards already identified.

868A25C0DEBE4798A2F822A165149E3A.description: Explain the hierarchy of controls as a system for preventing hazards and reducing risk of injury in the workplace, including: elimination - physically removing the hazard; substitution - replacing the hazard; engineering controls - isolating people from the hazard; administrative controls - changing the way people work; and,  personal protective equipment - protecting workers with the use of personal protective equipment.

F7A461C5688E4F4889EF5F8EB51076AE.description: List examples of potential workplace hazards for each of the four categories within a variety of agribusiness workplaces.

DE9377B089C74A6D9C914A861648198B.description: Differentiate among the four occupational health and safety hazard categories including: • physical (e.g., heavy lifting, repetitive motion, slipping/tripping, working at heights, working alone, cuts and burns); chemical (e.g., chemicals, fumes, vapours and gases); biological (e.g., viruses, fungi, bacteria, mold; bodily fluids; sewage; animal/pet waste; and influenza); and, psychological (e.g., harassment and bullying, stress, fatigue and shift work).

E9112C3E199D4F93B209E6BFA2F715DE.description: Examine what a workplace hazard is.

10F1191F585545E7B44B1CF9D3410BCA.description: Research the financial penalties for failure to comply with the Saskatchewan Occupational Health and Safety Regulations.

AFBC8A5D0548454DAD4874F359EFDC79.description: Explain the benefits to employers and employees of the Saskatchewan Workers Compensation Act and the Meredith Principles.

CA0A319718E14E16832D0E28ED5D69D1.description: Assess when coverage from the Saskatchewan Workers’ Compensation Board is optional and when it is mandatory.

550E38FFB5664AF7B729E835AC48F527.description: Identify sections of the Saskatchewan Employment Act that apply to owners, employers, contractors, supervisors, suppliers, self-employed persons and workers as it relates to agribusiness operations.

2279DBBAECB3428BA20F59813C6399E5.description: Research employer, supervisor and employee responsibilities pertaining to occupational health and safety standards in the workplace as required by Saskatchewan and Canadian law.

7559F46A765D4CB4894564C9C6345E8F.description: Analyze the effect that costs of injury and equipment damage (e.g., down time, repair costs and insurance premiums) have on agribusiness profit margins

14A47F533925420C8ECE3734DB6AD692.description: Assess the impact of a workplace injury on individuals (e.g., self and others) and the business

D710EB6FCF264D978EB88B757744A628.description: Discuss the importance of workplace safety (e.g., to self and others, the business and society).

CD86D45C240440B5840A856F5307D0E2.description: Examine strategies for promoting and supporting safety and efficiency in the agribusiness workplace.

3E987D07388244AE89EF0073B8B6D1D8.description: Analyze a variety of given agribusiness scenarios, propose potential solutions for diversification and defend the best solution for each scenario

12795CB7DA084F198F958ADF01C5CB2E.description: Investigate features of, and eligibility and application requirements for, BRM programs.

A88739410492411582EB4DFD3616AA74.description: Identify the purpose of Business Risk Management (BRM) programs (e.g., AgriStability, AgriRecovery and AgriInvest).

C25C00271AA248008F2B709649F62865.description: Describe ways to analyze the success of a diversification strategy following its implementation.

421F981235174E62A2BD731A217C2D90.description: Assess the benefits (e.g., better livelihood for producers/farmers, increased variety of products in the marketplace and increased employment opportunities) and challenges (e.g., capital costs, financing and skillset required) associated with various agricultural diversification strategies.

7A9984645EFD443CAFF31C3949727E16.description: Examine ways in which agricultural diversification can be accomplished, such as: growing a variety of crops (i.e., crop diversification); implementing a recommended crop rotation; growing crops in a variety of locations (i.e., geographic diversification); varying revenue streams (e.g., a mixed operation that includes both crop and livestock or establishing an ancillary agriculture-related enterprise such as a seed cleaning plant, corral cleaning and manure spreading services or certified seed growing); and, • performing value-added activities to a primary agricultural commodity (e.g., producing flavoured honeys, a variety of beeswax products such as candles, and gift baskets as a honey producer).

020A70BB21D249D7BBF81D4AAC43A07A.description: Discuss the relationship between risk management and diversification within the context of agriculture.

90DDDEF5130342EF89CEA2B1DAB22132.description: Define the terms diversification and risk management.

3C2D97BE3CD74F999E36ACF37B37CB72.description: Examine types of risks (e.g., operational and financial) agribusiness owners may face.

2DAA36C90FCF4526B6C859EEF4317967.description: Assess opportunities for diversification in agriculture.

88F51FE681934C8B81958B9BD1F29D88.description: Envision oneself or another individual employed in the field of agribusiness in the future and describe the corresponding career journey including: a description of the position (e.g., location, occupation, employer, working conditions, duties/responsibilities, salary and benefits); skills, characteristics, attitudes, traits and interests that led to the career choice; education and training; mentorship opportunities accessed and offered to others; leadership opportunities; and, a summary of the supports provided by networks of individuals and organizations.

0F281626A8514780AF428155C3927B4C.description: Reflect on personal interests, skills, abilities and traits that could lead to a one or more personal career options in agribusiness.

FF5679C311EF43FB89E23904C66C347F.description: Examine opportunities (e.g., independence, increased self-confidence and pride in ownership) and challenges (e.g., stress, anxiety, business succession, and mental health and well-being) associated with being an agribusiness owner

FC4D461FA91B452EBDD2CDAE73D23EA9.description: Debate the statement, “Growing up on a farm is necessary for a successful career in agribusiness.”

BE34EBDD3E5C4984BDE7B2B1DFBB9512.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of such employment programs from both the employer and worker perspectives.

9FC2EEBFB0874F12A2D5624EBDEFEBC9.description: Research the availability of, and eligibility requirements for, employment programs (e.g., Seasonal Agricultural Worker Program or Temporary Foreign Worker) that attempt to fill vacancies in Canadian primary agriculture

23E18C956F044D78891C5D676E3736A5.description: Identify current and forecasted career opportunities and employment trends, including labour surpluses or shortages, in the field of agribusiness in Saskatchewan, Canada and the world.

4562B45F6BD04A75959982E20095D9AB.description: Research and describe the diverse opportunities (e.g., farm and livestock management, food science, agricultural and rural policy, foreign trade, entrepreneurship, commodity marketing and economic development) related to the field of agribusiness.

A86770829DD744BDB93B07FFEF33B360.description: Analyze opportunities for a successful career in agribusiness.

2DD656E5FE27481FAA90697D004D4E9B.description: Research the mandate of a variety of agricultural organizations such as the Saskatchewan Food Processors’ Association, the Prairie Machinery Manufacturers’ Association and commodity associations as well as federal and provincial government agencies such as Agriculture and Agri-food Canada, Canadian Food Inspection Agency, Saskatchewan Agriculture and Food, Health Canada, Canadian Renewable Fuels Association, Saskatchewan Health and Public Health in maintaining product quality and safety.

509327F74C184DB7A6BAC07D8C32ACBB.description: Predict potential repercussions of events such as an outbreak of food poisoning or other foodborne illness, an anthrax outbreak among cattle herds, an outbreak of clubroot disease in canola crops, rail blockades and protests that are indicative of, or could lead to, a lack of quality assurance in the agriculture industry.

FDC3364C183343ECB8266F567990FEF2.description: Investigate: rules and regulations (e.g., CE Mark Certification on equipment and the European Union Animal Health Law) imposed by other jurisdictions that affect the exporting of Saskatchewan and Canadian agriculture products and services into foreign markets; Canadian rules and regulations (e.g., equipment manuals available in both English and French and mandatory labelling of prepackaged food products) that affect the importing of foreign agriculture products and services into Saskatchewan and Canada; interprovincial rules and regulations that might impact the flow of agricultural products and services among Canadian provinces; and, urban, rural, municipal and band rules and regulations (e.g., licensing and road bans) that impact the flow of agricultural products and services within Saskatchewan.

C1F3200079954993AE80EEF6AC61357A.description: Discuss the role that producers and consumers can play in influencing the development and introduction of rules and regulations in the agriculture industry

4A5E7D12D1C9490D8A20CFBD4D29790A.description: Reflect on individual responsibility for knowing and complying with rules and regulations applicable to the agriculture industry for those involved in it.

7D3508CFB87C47E99E53CC7CF20E77BC.description: Classify rules and regulations for the agriculture industry according to the level of government (i.e., municipal, band, provincial and federal) that is responsible for implementing them.

A7E18DE51C764C0CBF29DEEFD00A73C7.description: Explain the role of municipal, band, provincial and federal governments in establishing and enforcing rules and regulations for the agriculture industry.

9964B6542589441C83F7F61C9613C77B.description: Examine the alignment of current Saskatchewan and Canadian agriculture policy with First Nations and Métis worldviews (e.g., stewardship of the land)

D06D634E996F410C9254D4E6D9D8E5F2.description: Research post-colonial legislation and regulations that impacted, and continue to impact, agricultural activity among First Nations and Métis peoples.

4BBC78F3C0AF4A4593A42120B8A9F1E2.description: Identify rules and regulations (i.e., agriculture policy) that apply to the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan and Canada today

AFE620B9D9694E43B5B66F83937448BE.description: Describe what quality assurance means within the context of agriculture.

F50490931CF64787ADE44DF7E0628C42.description: Assess the importance (e.g., product quality and safety) of rules and regulations throughout the supply chain.

8790DAC21A1645149EF5414DFC03208E.description: Assess rules and regulations that apply to the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan and Canada.

1D808D7ECD9E4EA3A8B1EC4ABBA37929.description: Design a marketing strategy for an agriculture product or service of choice that includes adjustments for external factors such as changes in supply in demand or increases in production costs.

3A941E3B2D7844DAB0990B0AC1B6C34D.description: Examine factors (e.g., cultural differences, language barriers, currency exchange and different time zones) that need to be considered, and ways to effectively deal with them, when marketing to customers globally.

BECE6EE2B68845F1AD3C5A8A45455F39.description: Analyze the marketing strategies used by a variety of agribusiness enterprises.

5988718D110F4CB8AAC333105F47B5AD.description: Identify organizations (e.g., Saskatchewan Trade & Export Partnership) that assist provincial businesses, including agribusiness enterprises, in accessing global marketing opportunities.

1E3D42B511424FB8859BF5C6751D9A6C.description: Describe the basic steps in marketing an agricultural commodity, product or service within the community, province or country and around the world.

0CE9C27450484CECB27C8A1686D3F3B8.description: Analyze statistics related to the exporting of Saskatchewan agricultural products and services.

794B30C8B2D144A59F4386CC3459D99D.description: Analyze statistics related to the exporting of Saskatchewan agricultural products and services.

BEAB1EC423844055BB0BB0BF80586416.description: Identify local, provincial, national and international markets for a variety of Saskatchewan agricultural products or services.

4A50729855CB4E7FA9B8443584429A19.description: Assess the application of the Marketing Mix for a variety of agribusiness enterprises within the community or province.

CF35AFD703044D3C96BE6EA1B880D0FB.description: Examine the advantages and disadvantages of traditional (e.g., print and radio) and digital (i.e., online) marketing strategies as part of the place and promotion components of the Marketing Mix.

F87D02FA86214DEE9B196B379EE3D7F8.description: Explore factors to be considered for each of the components of the Marketing Mix

E6DE55C5FFF64E499719D9F408868A2C.description: Identify the four Ps of marketing (i.e., product, price, place and promotion) known as the Marketing Mix.

ABF70FA0F7CC478CB0ADCAF6C7DA11E8.description: Describe the interchangeability and interdependency of buyer-seller roles (e.g., farmer/producer as buyer and seller, and grocery store owner as buyer and seller) within agribusiness.

04AE582144714B7FA776472562830947.description: Research strategies (e.g., building trust and competitive pricing) for developing and maintaining strong buyer-seller relationships.

6B40E07241764F63B7D0BD4C6F514F6A.description: Discuss the importance of a good buyer-seller relationship for agribusiness success.

F67EB349FAA0408FA34CD7764F1B6E7A.description: Examine a variety of marketing strategies used in agribusiness.

7FF95C95464943C892EB1C957C436E70.description: Justify the increasing involvement of farmers or producers in communications and conversations (e.g., with regulators, government and consumers) around food and production practices.

94F04F16E6C04C158DC1D7C3D02A3B2E.description: Identify communication tools (e.g., software applications; video conferencing and videotelephony; text messaging; electronic mail; blogging and videologging [vlogging]; print and broadcast media; and social media), the skills required to use them effectively, and when and why they might be used in agriculture.

1A1844F2B3F54A6ABAF784FF1C4010BF.description: Research sources of credible information that support decision-making at every stage of the supply chain.

0F359612112B4BA68E0FCE0E37ACC316.description: Discuss ways to determine the credibility of a source of information.

234FF3C5D4C74FEEAAA2BAE5F0A4C422.description: Examine types of information needed at every stage of the supply chain for a variety of agricultural products

9F592C26BF5343368C0865A650CFD205.description: Assess the importance of access to reliable information through all stages of the supply chain.

331D23307376489EA89614A64A5DC2AC.description: Role-play and analyze situations that demonstrate effective and/or ineffective negotiation skills within an agriculture context.

C65F8121627C4403BEBBAF77E2BAC8A8.description: Identify strategies for negotiating better business deals within agribusiness.

04524F7B89BB4DC3AC421A62798249AA.description: Assess the role that negotiation plays in effective communication within agribusiness.

9B8081D732C94E1EBD43187DCD36C85C.description: Reflect on personal ability to communicate effectively in a variety of situations.

0BED413FAB0F429090C75146083732CA.description: Examine the importance of effective communication skills (e.g., speaking, public speaking, writing, listening and reading) for those employed in agribusiness.

9BC59A1E3C144E38B5F06C58022ABDE4.description: Develop effective information gathering and communication skills commonly used in agribusiness.

A1A7580035EC48EE87AA7BB301B60A23.description: Information and Effective Communication for Agribusiness (Core)

69CCDEB6841642BDABC4F1617032AD4B.description: Identify a problem or issue that currently exists in the agricultural supply chain and propose an innovative solution to the problem.

C9AB398AE8CA4B29A9C4078F06B0DC9B.description: Predict and describe the future impact of innovative ideas and practices on agribusiness in Saskatchewan and Canda.

BEBE0985F433473EB6EEF78238DA762A.description: Debate issues (e.g., technology use agreements [e.g., for seed], right to repair [R2R] movement, energy use, ethics and safety, use of antibiotics in livestock and environmental concerns) related to the use of various innovative technologies and practices in agriculture.

09320C1F90174CC9B1E5562EFB1C607F.description: Research programs and services offered by organizations (e.g., Prairie Agricultural Machinery Institute [PAMI], Innovation Saskatchewan, Saskatchewan Cattlemen’s Association, Crop Development Centre [CDC], Vaccine and Infections Disease Organization [VIDO], the Food Centre, the AgKnowledge Centre and Synchotron) that support the research, development and implementation of technology in Saskatchewan’s agriculture industry.

54B786ACA70E42C4B7A093A773A8E6BC.description: Identify benefits realized by the agriculture industry through research, development and implementation of innovative ideas and practices.

F663C13E172548B6A67BE6CA06BADAC3.description: Examine examples of innovative technologies (e.g., drones, autonomous tractors and robots) and other innovations (e.g., production cost insurance, business risk management programs and urban farms) used in agribusiness today

CCAD2AB869D047688C726C96D2EAF5BC.description: Describe the four areas of technology that impact the agriculture industry: mechanization and automation (e.g., equipment and processes); crops (e.g., seed, herbicides and fertilizer); livestock (e.g., genetics); and, data (e.g., collection, interpretation and usage).

7B73CEEEA959471680540874B18BD90F.description: Discuss reasons (e.g., global competition, efficiencies, safety and cost savings) for the research, development and implementation of innovative ideas and practices.

F69F3401DA0A408AB079C018EA0F63D2.description: Debate the risks (e.g., cost and wasting resources) and rewards (e.g., reducing costs and providing a better-quality product) often associated with innovation.

1F4AB4DB01744F0FA3D731004C3FD158.description: Explore innovation and its impact on agribusiness.

D988819ED1A64A5EBD482A2B45092A1F.description: Assess the role of technology and innovation in supporting and growing Saskatchewan’s agriculture industry.

5DD05D7F5AC1460395BBEA2C10D78496.description: Reflect on the role that individuals and agribusiness enterprises throughout the agricultural supply chain can play in supporting and building public trust in the agriculture industry.

F0F54D17293740328C9ABED54AB38080.description: Explore the mandates as well as current and past initiatives of a variety of organizations (e.g., Farm & Food Care Saskatchewan, Agriculture in the Classroom and 4-H Saskatchewan) in fostering public trust in agriculture.

ACE41FB9E50B45D287D01BA294B57F4D.description: Research current provincial and federal government strategies and programs for fostering public trust in agriculture.

C9BCBEAB316541DDAE8BF8BAF3DC9D7F.description: Investigate the advantages of, and processes for, obtaining HACCP, ISO and CFIA certifications.

948BCD876E7E42809C17BAD310EF01F7.description: Examine the role of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) in the Canadian agriculture industry.

D01F585A23FF4C8499F1DC95DB0057C1.description: Research standards set by the Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) and International Standards Organization (ISO) food safety management systems.

E0E3944A151E4E07B3D693F1B7F8AE81.description: Assess the importance of, and ways to determine, the credibility of a source of information.

642BF78B84F04010B98A564BC8A9DC8E.description: Identity sources (e.g., social media, newspaper, television and word of mouth) often accessed by the public for information on the agriculture industry.

2EC652B3E594485081811A029C03AEDD.description: Discuss the potential impact (e.g., counter-productive public policy and regulatory changes) on the industry of negative consumer perceptions of agriculture.

174C7887449E49F3A94CE7D21D3151D3.description: Explain principles of public trust such as transparency of industry practices, continuous improvement of practices, evidence-based decisions and collaboration with relevant experts.

BABE0D1AF86646A9A145CBB0A4AD7B16.description: Describe the concept of public trust within the context of Saskatchewan agriculture.

022C0A331EF74D679C8D469238160C64.description: Examine consumer expectations (e.g., safety, affordability, ethical production and traceability) of food produced by the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan and Canada.

E1A314AAC3154C3DA45C595F782D05CF.description: Examine the importance of public trust to the agriculture industry.

9AE8F619941149FB9DA07E031709696E.description: Assess the role of agribusiness in supporting growth of the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan and the economies of Saskatchewan and Canada.

73E3AF3C49864905877CDA02C949A99F.description: Debate the opinion that the family farm is disappearing in Saskatchewan and Canada.

3058C9C293BF455094B910060C5AE75F.description: Explore opportunities and challenges currently faced by agribusiness enterprises in Saskatchewan.

98E151AA4622439B94A5F9418D2D8984.description: Describe factors (e.g., physical resources [e.g., soil, water and climate], transportation, human resources, population and educational institutions) that have contributed to the establishment of agribusiness enterprises within the local area and/or other parts of Saskatchewan.

593A409727984527BCDB067021C5F29A.description: Identify agribusiness enterprises and activities within the local area and/or Saskatchewan and classify according to the stage(s) of the agricultural supply chain they support.

F6130373D7904B4FBAC39BF9758D914A.description: Research the evolution of agriculture to agribusiness and describe the growing interdependence between agriculture (e.g., farmers and producers) and other businesses that support the industry.

4875BBB6B1164F6D97BD4B1C7EB74F6A.description: Analyze the role of agribusiness within the agriculture industry.

6E41F5A7DDFF457EBE1F8A800DFAA223.description: Examine the effect of events (e.g., pandemic, trade wars, transportation issues, inclement weather and labour strikes) on various stages of the agricultural supply chain.

780894BEFF5742DA9123B5F93ABCDF68.description: Investigate factors (e.g., inputs to the product or service, processes and techniques, human resources, safety and environmental standards and rules and regulations) which may influence or affect agribusiness enterprises at each stage of the agricultural supply chain.

BED089DD4858421FBA6F91856F1D3674.description: Assess examples of agribusiness enterprises that support activities at every stage of the agricultural supply chain.

37E3209631224132A3FD71DD3496FE9B.description: Examine the kinds of activities typically associated with each stage of the supply chain for several agriculture products destined for domestic and global markets.

7FB12E6B8DC4467597955CE01247776A.description: Identify the stages typically associated with the agricultural supply chain, including: inputs; production; marketing and selling of primary products; transportation and distribution; processing and manufacturing; •grading; packaging;  storing;  merchandising;  wholesaling;  retailing and services;  preparation and consumption;  resource and waste recovery;  research and development;  health, safety and environment; and, • technology, sales and support services.

A1B8E507D63B4FB6BE2E9667824F207D.description: Investigate agribusiness activity and enterprises throughout the agricultural supply chain.

2C99B3918EFF4FC49C0F0C184DB41D8B.description: Trace the impact of the multiplier effect on an agriculture product (e.g., food product) from the selling price to the consumer to the selling price by the producer.

B7507347B9B946A3BB35EA76C98EF899.description: Investigate innovations in agriculture that are attributed to Saskatchewan.

DB6303BBBD9A43D08E641A8334F8D225.description: Identify current events, trends and issues affecting the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan and Canada.

1B8F33F6B6E64AC0A27F49C0D47B9642.description: Investigate other factors (e.g., climate change, activity in global markets and legislation) that may impact agriculture in Saskatchewan.

CC16C726F5AD4D4E8D5ED80392B6EF70.description: Predict the impact of changes in the provincial, national and global population (i.e., growth and decline) on Saskatchewan agriculture.

CA75E824FD9B419AA50E8A6BEDC241FF.description: Assess provincial and federal legislation that apply to farmland ownership in Saskatchewan and Canada.

6D9FB19ADB0C4EC683E3BDF16DC84B49.description: Examine challenges (e.g., access to capital and financing, and limited agricultural knowledge and skill) faced by First Nations and Métis communities in establishing and growing farming operations and agribusiness enterprises in Saskatchewan.

8D330ECBB4044B9F8E3BBB653F841E9A.description: Analyze the growth of agriculture enterprises among First Nations communities in recent decades and the factors (e.g., signing of The 1992 Treaty Land Entitlement [TLE] Framework Agreement) that have contributed to the growth.

E74232090D9D4CA28009504DCE9958B0.description: Investigate factors (e.g., family members/owners incorporating for tax reasons) that have contributed to the establishment and growth of largescale farming operations in the province.

C114266D94604D7F936A55F5371A6B19.description: Chart the growth of various aspects of the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan over the past 25 years, using measures such as metric tonnes (e.g., crops), acres (e.g., farm size), kilograms (e.g., milk), cash receipts (e.g., livestock), numbers (e.g., farms or producers) and Gross Domestic Product.

5879F15F0D4F4A09B849C77705CB4A56.description: Research the economic, environmental, cultural and social significance of Saskatchewan’s agriculture industry locally, provincially, nationally and globally.

76BFD560994049108189ADFD305AC4D6.description: Analyze the significance of Saskatchewan’s agriculture industry.

BAD4B620105F41CA8D6AD8828F1C6F31.description: Define, give examples of, and appropriately use terms commonly associated with the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan, including, but not limited to: primary production; production agriculture; commodities; producers; consumers; markets; diversification; food; fibre; non-food; value-added agriculture; diversified agriculture; and, related services.

E618922EDDB14D068CEED3D85A5038BB.description: Analyze the roles (e.g., farmers, landlords and agribusiness entrepreneurs) of First Nations and Métis peoples in Saskatchewan agriculture.

66E5794744064A5490DD726BF7D6B0E5.description: Assess differences in agricultural practices and commodities produced in various regions of Saskatchewan including within First Nations and Métis communities.

EBADA0F0B4CC472A9636EF9E825986FF.description: Investigate the presence and impact of the three categories of agriculture, known as the three Fs (i.e., food, fuel and fibre) within the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan.

6E10527DEAF148D4BC45654C6B5EFB0A.description: Identify agricultural products imported and exported by Saskatchewan and classify each as primary production or value-added.

16E81BD460834B5AA9FFC28DED0C0814.description: Research agricultural products and/or services produced in Saskatchewan for both types of markets.

DC9D12F78F9343A3A5C325CBCE58FB55.description: Justify the role of Saskatchewan’s agriculture industry in serving both domestic and international markets.

CA0FE104F8E24159955D72B3A56BA1F5.description: Discuss ways (i.e., primary production and value-added) that agricultural products are sold on domestic and international markets.

8345AB203780406FA39439E803E2E82F.description: Differentiate between domestic (i.e., within Canada) and international (i.e., export or trade) markets.

A76985EC872F423DB313E5D2B41A29CB.description: Describe personal perception of the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan.

77E188F6A13B41228078AD54B00BD359.description: Analyze the diversity of Saskatchewan’s agriculture industry.
